lg.l: In the wide, big world of the Vidhyādharas
[In] a grove [with] flowers that open [with] nectar,
A vidhyādhara warrior who was engaged in festivities
Along with lady love [with] black carp[-like], long eyes
For [the sake of] the God of love
Saying, [=realising], ‘This is the day in which
the festival of Indra in [that] one flourishing city is held’,
The very fast demons having grouped together,
Becoming those that lost to the king [whose] anklets touch [his feet]
That protected the royal city with the zeal of the tiger,
As the Lord [= the Vidhyādhara?] order for the sake of the king with the perfect lance
The great, big Bhūta that removed the deceit [= the Asuras]
That dispatched upon [those Asuras], so that [their] hearts, having appeared, abounded in darkness,
We will even see the place in which [he] ate the offerings, [they] having been placed [there],
Having guarded Amarāvati, having obtained [the offering] from the celestials,
Having given [it] to those here [= the royal family of Pukār],
Let us see the [good] state of the places of five types
That united upon the world, without any manner of lie,
Of a superiority worth of [their good] status!
Let us [also] witness the songs of the Veena of Nārada that knows joy,
The Vāram song of the ancient girl,
And the dance of [she] with pretty hips
[She] who appeared at the beginning of the lineage of the lady Mātavi
As he with the thousand eyes' ears filled up [with music],
Ūruppaci being she who did not grant the drama [performance],
As the Veena lost its auspiciousness,
Saying, 'This lady -- stay upon the earth!'
[The Vidhyādhara] saying, ‘Oh you with a waist [like] a Tuṭi drum,
Let us bow to the leader of the immortals!’,
After having shown [her] the Himalayas with peaks,
The city of Uñcai, the forest of Viñcam
The Vēṅkaṭam mountain and the land of the Kāvēri [river] With a produce that cannot be endured [= that is too much],
Having reached Pukār [with] gardens in which flowers expanded,
Having shown, in the same manner that was spoken of [earlier],
He who witnessed the joyous festival of the ancient town
Of the abundant one [= the one with abundant prosperity]
After having sung the song on Māyoṉ,
The songs of four types on the Bhūtas [Of each of the four] Varna [caste?]
And [the song on] the moon that roams the sky,
That was danced by he of the lofty Himalayas,
As the three[tiered] city burned, as the Gods prayed,
As the big arrow [with] a burning face [=tip] listened to [his] command,
Upon the Araṅkam of the Pārati dance
In which the Pārati dance was danced,
So that the nature of the cīr [notes?] glittered, [and]
So that the lack of [any good] nature left, [= as mediocrity left]
As he of the face [of the four] directions
That stood before the chariot watched,
The wide Pāṇṭaraṅkam dance that was danced by Pārati,
Among the dances that were danced by he who was the colour of kajal
For the sake of overcoming the deceit of Kaṃsa,
The Tuṭi dance danced by he who crossed/vanquished the power
of the spirit Cūr, before whom he stood [as an equal],
Having appeared in an arena of water-waves
In the middle of the big ocean,
The Kuṭai dance that was dance in the front[line]
By he who made fall the umbrella
So that the Avuṇar, having been made to throw down [their] weapons
The Kuṭam dance that was danced by he who measured the long world
Having walked in the middle of the street of the big town of Bāṇāsura,
The dance of Pēṭi that was danced by Kāma
In a disguise of femininity that altered [his] masculinity,
The dance of Marakkāl that was danced by the dark one
[As] she who did not bear the cruel deeds of the demons with burning anger,
The Pāvai dance that was danced by the perfect one of brilliance/Tiru
So that the demons with a fighting, hot countenance left,
And Kaṭaiyam dance that was danced by the girl Ayirāṇi
Inside the north entrance, [she] having stood at the paddy field,
Watch all the eleven dances of the tradition
That does not leave [the rules of its] place or its dance,
Having sat in a grove where flowers open [with] pollen,
The Mātavi of the lineage of Mātavi that I had spoken of
And, aside from [that] Vidhyādhara befitting of excellence
Who reached [a state] of joy, having narrated [these things] to [his] lady-love,
The festival of he of the sky [Indra] that was watched [by many],
Having come in a manner unknown to they who lived in the sky,
The dancing, the adornment and the festivities coming to an end;
In order to please he who stayed with a sulking countenance,
[She,] having massaged [on her] tresses so that beauty is obtained
With the fragrant smell of oil into which good water
Which was soaked with ten spices, five scents,
Having fed [those] tresses as tender as flowers
That were made dry with incense
[With] a rich paste of every type of deer musk,
On the tender toes that are befitting of beauty
That were dyed with red lac,
Adorning, so that it is suitable, the foot with
Having fastened on the thigh a close-set thigh-ring,
Wearing with [good] nature a flower[-patterned?] fine cloth
[Fastened by] glistening waistband of thirty-two pearl[strings],
Adorning a shoulder-bangle of pure gems
- Into which was braided a desirable necklace -
Adorning, so that it is suitable, a picturesque bracelet,
A hand-bangle of red-gold, a Pariyakam bracelet, a pure bangle,
And many bangles of coral [and] to the wrist with streaked hair,
Adorning, in order to hide the tender fingers [like] Malabar glory lilies,
A finger ring that is bent [into the shape of] the gaping mouth of the Vāḷai fish,
A finger ring of shining sapphire that shines with lustre,
[And one that shines in] red lustre,
And a close-set stalk[-shaped ring] of emeralds
Adorning the inner part of the pretty neck
With the craftwork of an ornamental thread with fine links [made of] chain,
Concealing the small of the back [of the neck]
With a chain fit to be made
Of desirable, pure gems that flowed from link to link,
Adorning, so that it has beauty,
A pair of earrings that obtain fitness [to be worn],
Of rounded diamonds in alternation with [stones] of Indra blue,
Adorning, so that it is glorious, the kajal[-coloured], wet tresses
That are linked [to] a head ornament [and] a forehead ornament
[Made of] a right-whirling [conch] of an ample nature,
Kōvalaṉ rejoicing in [both] union and love-quarrelling,
She who sat in the bedroom that is befitting of song,
Being she who wished, with [much] longing,
To see the retreating people who go to the great waters,
Saying, ‘the full moon has come to the ancient village that has a [beautiful] form',
Playing [=bathing] in the ocean [with] seashore groves in which palmyra [fronds] open,
As the beaks of birds [among] lotuses in ponds called out,
As the rooster showed the midnight’s breaking into dawn,
As the silver lamp dispelled the middle of the darkness [= midnight],
Along with he of the chest that was adorned with a garland [Kōvalaṉ],
[She] having been adorned with great adornments,
As with hands [as] abundant [as] the sky mounted a mule,
As she with eyes [as] beautiful [as] a deer climbed onto a cart,
In the street with shop counters, abundant with storied houses
[With] piles of rich treasures that were heaped up in many crores,
Auspicious servant-girls, [their] jewels tinkling, having lifted sapphire lamps
- of [the kind of] lamps decorated with blossom[-patterns], -
Scattering scutch grass from blossoming creepers,
Having properly crossed the seat of the lady Tiru
In which those who wander move [about] on both sides/places,
Having gone to the middle of the city streets
That was lofty, the waters with crocodiles [= the oceans]
Reaching, having gone to the [city] quarters in the evening,
Where flags at the grain[-sellers’] streets
Like expanses of expanding waves of pure sand [from] sandy tracts
Having been raised, spoke of people who moved [from] arable regions
For the sake of wealth given by ships;
The sections in which colour [pastes], sandal paste, flowers and powders
Were made, the lamps of those who sell [them],
The hand-made lamps of artisans of hand-made [goods],
The ancient [=long-burning] by the dumplings of dumpling-sellers,
The dark, terracotta pot[-like] lamps [on] legs [= stands] of pancake-sellers,
The lamps at doors of women who declare sales [i.e., the price],
The lamps of those who sell [at] a price fish [from] shining waters,
The lamps of fishing boats of fishermen with transverse [= horizontal] nets,
The undying lamps of those [from other] countries, [who] change/move in languages,
And the lamp of watchmen of big stores
Gathering together pleasantly, not knowing their numerical limit [= too many to count],
In an area with swelling waters with fragrant blossoms of lotus,
That were a sight in which [even] a white mustard [seed] was seen,
The flower-creeper [= Mātavi] having united with her group of girls [amidst] playing Poytal,
At a seashore grove with blue waterlilies [in] a fence of Kaitai trees
That appear gloriously in a fence of Marutam,
The sights that escape comparison in which row [after] row [of goods] were lifted [on stalls],
The place in which the wealth of swaying ships mixed together,
Of multitudes of rare goods [from] the mountains, and multitudes of rare goods [from] the seas,
women [on] the dancing ground [= stage], and women [on] the singing ground [= stage],
Near a surrounding curtain at the place that held a multitude [of people],
[Just] like the top[-class] day in which Karikāl Vaḷavaṉ
Of great praise that touched the skies
In garb of every manner appearing, obtaining distinction, On the grounds that were engaged in the festival,
As the unrestrained crowd of the four castes that gathered
At the big river of Kāviri that softens the seashore,
Over there, inside a fence that makes an enclosure
That chased away the smell of fish [from] the sea,
Under the shade of a Puṉṉai tree,
[They] having gone together, as a painted curtain surrounded [them],
To the expanse of new sands,
Upon a bed with white legs that had been made with a canopy,
Mātavi with long eyes [like] big blossoms,
Having received in the proper way the good lute with a perfect stem
[From] the hand of Vacanamālai who stood [there], being exhausted,
Sat down according to [correct] principles, beside Kōvalaṉ.
